job_title: Seasonal Research Technician in Hettinger, ND
pros: Emphasis on quality training. Great supervisor and co workers.
cons: I worked independently most of the time so it was a bit lonely at times.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Fargo, ND
pros: Great and friendly people to work with. The faculty and staff make themselves available to help students. The grad students are also very cool. Very laid-back environment (of course depends on your PI) but in general very nice people.
cons: The laid-back environment is good but it is also the greatest downside in the department. Some students receive pretty much no guidance from their PIs, which in turn causes students to stay in the program for 7-8 years doing a Ph.D. that is supposed to only take 5 years. Some PIs (I can think of at least 2) are downright toxic and awful to their students. Making their students cry or quit the program. Another con is the school is cutting down budgets, which also limits access to some resources for students. The department lacks passion, drive, and a clear goal. At this rate, if they do not turn things around, the department will cease to exist in a couple of years, which would be tragic, in truth!

pros: The university itself is a great environment for research and extension.
cons: My former department was not a good place to work. The work environment was tense if not toxic due to previous drama that new employees were not apart of, but are associated with because of their supervisor's involvement. Additionally, respect is lacking and scientific integrity is dubious at best. I was told that if a reviewer brought up issues with statistics in a paper, just to forget them and submit the manuscript elsewhere. This was after a lengthy discussion on analysis issues. Female students/staff were subtly talked down towards, and faculty often had strong favoritism. There was an incident where a student was screamed and sworn at. Work was not taken seriously by superiors and some often disappeared for half the day and would cancel or continually reschedule meetings until they were never fulfilled. Credit was not given where credit was due either.

pros:
- Free room and board
- Some good hall directors to work under
- Community
- Developed friendships among the staff I was placed with
- Flexibility
cons:
This is based of off stories and feedback heard from multiple fellow RAs and my own person experience:

- It is clear ResLife does not care about its staff
- ResLife has forced us to work out of contract and perform jobs we were not hired and are not paid for
- ResLife is unorganized and does not care about the amount of unnecessary work they shovel on us (sometimes at the last minute)
- Any complaints are entertained in a manner as if ResLife cares but in a way that wears out the RAs until the they give up on what they were looking to fix. Or, the complaints are just outright ignored.
- Some hall directors are a NIGHTMARE to work under
- You could land in an apartment setting where it would be possible to make your own meals, but some dorms still require you to buy a meal plan rather than take the money from the scholarship to make food on your own that is more healthy and convenient. This is a real problem for Niskanen RAs in the winter months who have to walk blocks to the nearest cafeteria.
- Ending up in a single room in the high rises can be rough. It gets worse if residents in the suite choose to gang up and have an attitude toward you just because you're the RA (think about the fact that you will live in this situation 24/7 for the year). Note, this is not always the case, but just remember you will be with freshman who are still transitioning from the "high school-clique" mentality.
- All female dorms are a pain to work in and ResLife/Hall Directors do not care about what you will experience

review_title: Much better opportunities available for men than women
pros: opportunity to continue your own education with 1 course/ semester if you wish to do so. A lot of nice people work there.
cons: Sexist. Rules/ policies are randomly followed or enforced by administration. Splendid opportunities will be presented to male employees while female employees will be asked to teach less desirable courses and take on extra classes. I watched a male colleague get paid to vacation in Europe with his family (when he was supposed to do a particular job) and when the work he was paid to do was not done, administration demanded that the female faculty work overtime and for no additional pay to do the job that the male colleague had been paid to do. And then they gave the male colleague Paid Leave after his paid family vacation/ work abdication. True Story.

review_title: Good hours, less than stellar compensation and respect
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Fargo, ND
pros: I was surprised at how much I like living in Fargo.  The community so far is great.  The campus climate overall is quite open.  The job pays my tuition and a monthly salary.
cons: Like any job, the faculty in my department have formed cliques. Their arguments are often played out through the graduate students like pawns.  The facilities and technology leave something to be desired.  My office accumulates a fine coating of soot from the coal plant when left undisturbed over the weekend.

pros:
Easily one of my favorite jobs I've had so far. My job was with Information Technology Services, and the environment is really relaxed and supportive. It's an awesome position if you are willing to learn a lot of different programs and help others. I feel NDSU is supportive of growth at least to student workers.

As a university there are a lot of different types of jobs available, and honestly I can only speak from the perspective of a student worker, but I felt like they did look within for advancement for instance at least in the Information Technology Services department. You feel like you are working as a team and its a great starter for people who want tech experience.
cons: Because of the way the visas work, international students will have to cap their hours at 20 hours

review_title: Great research experience with cutting edge technology
pros: I worked in an applied research laboratory at the Center for Nanoscale Science and Engineering (CNSE).  The research was engaging, fun, and collaborative between scientists and engineers.  The equipment was cutting edge and unique for a university laboratory.  The salary was excellent for a university lab.  While I was employed at CNSE the pay was competitive with industry which can be rare in an academic setting.
cons: The only major drawback of working at CNSE, from my perspective, was the uncertainty of employment surrounding the competitive research funding cycle.  This was ultimately the reason I sought out employment elsewhere and left the University.

review_title: Robust potential held back by micromanagement of a myopic administration
pros:
When you ask anyone that works in the academic institution, the majority will answer steady paycheck and benefits.
The potential for strong research and academic empowerment is there, like any other higher education institution, if it is under a visionary leadership, which currently it is not, as of 2016.
cons:
-People with initiative should look elsewhere. Frustration and stress will set quickly due to a very slow pace and lack of true strategic planning.

-The institutional administration is not particularly welcoming of people's ideas if they do not hold a doctorate or post-doctorate behind their title. As such, many directors and VP's based mostly their decisions on theory rather than practice or industry expertise.

-The focus is heavily on athletics. As an academic university, careers should be very focused and oriented toward students and academic development. Academic development is poor and when asked, students that are above the median feel underserved. The campus as of 2016, and since 2010, has had a very conservative administration with very little knowledge about how to empower academics in today's age. They focus, rather, on catering to the fanfare of sports and alumni mixers. This is not what an academic institution needs. Educational leaders, visionaries and people who understand technology appreciate academic success and empowerment of students. They don't just use it to make them look good in social networks.

-Lack of enthusiasm and caring by people who are close to retirement, coasting to collect a paycheck.

pros: Small-town feel.  Many amenities.  Friendly People. Lots of local bars and eateries.  Good local arts advocacy.  Cheap housing can be had.
cons: Cold winters, Hot summers, Road construction all summer long.  Fully dependent on Football team and corporate overlords.  PARKING IS HELL.

cons: Pay scales are far below competitive positions in the private sector. Some tasks are hard to perform if you need assistance from other departments.

review_title: I had an excellent experience with North Dakota State University
pros: Flexible timing, The co-workers were nice and easy going, Lot of opportunity to learn new technologies, Excellent work environment, Good supervisor
cons:
The payment is not very high, The chance to get to an industry is low, The freezing long cold winter.
Threat of flooding every spring.

pros: If you enjoy working in higher education then NDSU is the perfect place for you. Great students, friendly coworkers and a good benefit package.
cons: The location - NDSU is located in Fargo, ND where winter weather can hit in October and last through April and even into May. The temperatures drop below zero and stay there for most of January and February. Add wind chill on top of those subzero temps and it is awful

review_title: Worked in Information Technology Services as a Student Employee while I went to school full-time.
job_title: Communications and Web Specialist in Fargo, ND
pros: Good experience, laid back environment, friendly co-workers. The pace of workflow was easy to maintain and every so often, a challenging project would come up that would be rewarding to accomplish.
cons: Sometimes mundane tasks and the pay could have been a little better. Not much cross-training among different parts of the department.

review_title: low pay but worth it if you want free classes or are a student
job_title: IT Classroom Technician in Fargo, ND
pros: I work as a student in the IT department. very flexible with hours... amount I work as well as when I work. not stressful
cons: pay could have been better. sometimes I feel like we could have used more training for some skills

review_title: Graduate research and teaching assistant - Biology Dept
job_title: Graduate Research and Teaching Assistant in Fargo, ND
pros: The biology graduate programs are almost all fully financially supported with research and teaching assistanceships. There were many opportunities for collaboration with other labs and with the local USDA branch, mentorships, professional development, and direct teaching experience.
cons: low take home pay and long hours, but that is grad school.

pros: People care for each other and value your success, the area is growing and the university is a core part of that.
cons: Very cold in winter, which lasts almost half the year, flooding in spring, entertainment can be less than exciting at times

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Fargo, ND
pros: Being a graduate teaching assistant in North Dakota State University is always challenging and fun, students are generally highly motivated and curious to learn new materials and experience.
cons: The weather here is quite unpredictable, though it is usually cold and windy. Sometimes we get a sunny day today and the next day we might have a blizzard warning.

job_title: Food Scientist-product Development in Fargo, ND
pros: Opportunity to learn new methods, modern techniques. Meet other scientist from your field, good connections with other companies, what give us good opportunities to see different processes
cons: Really bad administration, it takes so long to process any request or any documents. Often documents get lost, and there is need to gather new ones.

pros: Good benefits and pay.  I enjoy my coworkers and have a great boss.  A lot of friendly and helpful people work here.  Good place for collaboration.  The School of Natural Resource Sciences has good family values.
cons: Poor dental plan.  Some of the University bureaucratic stuff gets annoying, but that is part of working at an University.

review_title: A laid back, but busy learning experience
pros: You get to learn at your own pace in a friendly environment while being challenged and learning a lot along the way.
cons: The enviroment may be a little too laid back, you don't feel encouraged to try harder than you need too.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Fargo, ND
pros: You can always find nice people, however there is not too many of them in NDSU. Officials show they want to help!
cons: Officials show they want to help, however they only important thing is getting tenure  for most Instructors and bringing money to school for officials. They quality of work is just a word!

pros:
The work environment was very friendly.
The hours were flexible.
It was close to where I lived.
Work wasn't hard.
cons: The pay wasn't stellar but it was better than minimum wage since it WAS just a part time summer job.

pros: Benefits are awesome, HR and university staff are so helpful. Friendly ambient. No traffic, hassle-free transportation, cost of living is very low for the standard
cons: Mostly locals people work here, which leads to no exposure to new people. Football is great, but universities are not just meant for football, worse leadership, do not higher education here

pros: Nothing I can think of.
cons:
If you want to destroy your career then it is the right place for you. Especially if you are an international student then forget about any future prospects let alone a job. 
Don't let anybody fool you, out of 10 only 2 international student gets any phone call. You can check the department's statistics to confirm.
Everybody has already written about no health insurance and low assistant so there is no need to repeat here. Wish Glassdoor let 0 or negative as a rating

review_title: It is a good place to conduct research here. But same time it is very boring here.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Fargo, ND
pros: Peaceful, very safe place, if you have family, it would be a good place for you.
cons: very boring, not much fun, not a ideal place for a young person like me

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Fargo, ND
pros: Good salary if you are thinking about staying here for one or two years. Benefits are great if you are a post doctoral researcher.
cons: It takes time to make your way up. You will spend a few years here before you can advance to the next step in your professional career.

pros: Good work environment and good starting salary. Very flexible and many benefits assuming you can work enough hours a week.
cons: It is a bit crazy working a shift because we can get many orders at once, but I enjoy the challenge.

review_title: University have very few departments and research is not great.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Fargo, ND
pros: Very nice place to live except weather. Very safe place and people are really friendly. University is located at nice place.
cons: Weather of Fargo is worst and university is running out of funds. Many professors lack good resources for research and quality too.

pros: Very supportive, good community, soaked in campus pride and tradition. Decent benefits if you're a man. Lots of neat little things to do in the local community as well.
cons: Very limited medical coverage or support for women's needs (birth control isn't covered, no maternity leave, insurance doesn't cover STI screaning, etc.)

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Fargo, ND
pros: Nice midwest people to work with.
cons: I've been studying Mechanical Eng. at NDSU for almost 7 years.  Most of the faculty does not have external funded projects to support their research, except Dr. Wu who is awarded an NSF project in nanomanufacturing.  Therefore, research ability of this school is limited.

review_title: Had two of the most productive years ever
pros: Worked as a Resident Assistant for two years at NDSU. The Hall Director really invests time and effort in the residents and in Resident Assistants' growth. Informative training session, and a flexible and understanding work environment.
cons: Need to have the ability to balance between working and studying

job_title: Chemistry Graduate Research Assistant in Fargo, ND
pros: All the instruments you would need are available. Some good professors.
cons: A lot of poor lab management by professors that gets worse each year. Some "perma-docs" are present. They changed the classes so that students are pushed through the system very quickly, but then the students don't learn basic chemistry that is extremely necessary.

pros: Adjunct teaching at NDSU is a great way to get supplemental income.  Did not have to be involved with institutional politics.
cons: Pay is reasonable on a per/credit basis for part-time work.  Even adjuncts are expected to attend the pre-semester all-day meetings.  No parking passes.

review_title: Fargo nice city to live apart of its cold winter. Good School with lots of fun.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Fargo, ND
pros: Very nice people in Fargo, I enjoyed living in there. There a number of good professors, too. Overall good school.
cons: The mechanical engineering department has numbers of unprofessional teachers, be aware of them. Don't work with them, never.

pros: Good environment, stuff is great, great level of professors. Given is a little department (Agribusiness and Applied Economics) it is easy to get contact face to face with professors.
cons: The city is little and does not have a great social life. The weather (winter) is too hard and too long.

review_title: ITS- Great place to work as a student.
job_title: IT Help Desk in Fargo, ND
pros:
There's always a great group of people working here. Definitely a family dynamic, we help each other when possible
Very flexible schedule
Easy to get along with Full Time Employees
Everyone's very respectful
cons: Pay is rather low, but that's what you get for work-study.

pros: Full Fee waiver + Good Stipend. Good on campus food cout. weekend bowling an billiards. Good guidance from the faculty.
cons: Very Cold in winter and Smoking ban on campus. Expensive air fares to travel to big cities. Poor career guidance and center

pros: great social ambient, easy access to other places, great public transportation, good opportunities for students

pros: Health care and retirement.  Time off when needed.  Generally nice co workers in the IT field.
cons: In This field there is a small chance of promotion and pay raises.

pros: A university with unity of purpose
cons: Some very lazy tenured staff. Shameful abuse of a very decent school!

review_title: Being a graduate student my experience has been great
pros: Excellent research facilities, good professors..
cons: No work/life balance, city offers very little, outdated classrooms and buildings. Most of the university looks just like the way it was built in 1900s. Library needs an update.

pros: a university, an academic institution. good place for cunning people. non professional people are friendly but professionally not much cooperative

pros: everything like work culture,students,time we need to spend for our work and courses etc.,

review_title: Great university -- students, faculty, collegues, community
